Read the following text and make a flow-chart showing role and activities of Gazi Pir. (One is done for you):
According to some myths and legends, Gazi Pir was a Muslim saint who is said to have spread Islam in the parts of Bengal close to the Sundarbans. He was credited with many miracles. For example, he could supposedly calm dangerous animals and make them docile. He is usually depicted in paats or scroll paintings riding a fierce-looking Bengal tiger, a snake in his hand, but in no apparent danger. According to some stories, he also fought crocodiles who threatened the people of a region full of canals and creeks, indeed, a kind of watery jungle bordering the Bay of Bengal. Because of his alert and vigilant presence, all predatory animals were said to have been kept within bounds. It was also believed that he enabled villagers to live close to forests and jungles and cultivate their lands.
1. Close to the Sundarbans → 2 → 3 → 4 → 5 → 6.

questions.uddipok:
Summarize the following text.
Accessibility to higher education implies that students get the opportunity to get university education and sufficient
support from educational institutions. Increasing enrolment at the secondary and higher secondary level puts pressure on higher educational institutions. But due to limited capacity, only a small number of students may be enrolled in universities. Thus, each year a large number of students are denied access to higher education. Also, due to poverty and increase in educational expenses, students of the lower middle class do not get easy access to higher education. Moreover, those who get places in the universities have limited access to avail all kinds of diversified educational facilities relating to their study fields. Only about 12% of graduates enter higher educational institutions. More than 80% of these students are admitted to NU affiliated colleges. Others are absorbed by the public and private universities. In the last two decades, there has been a substantial rise in the number of students in private universities. According to the UGC Annual Report 2010, the number rose from 88,669 in 2005 to 2,00,752 in 2010.

sub_questions.explanation:
Accessibility to higher education means the opportunity to receive university education. Unfortunately, every year
many students do not get the privilege to enroll in universities. Poverty, limited capacity of the universities and high
educational expenses are some of the major causes. According to a survey, about 12 percent of graduates go for
higher education where 80 percent of them get admitted into NU affiliated colleges and the rest of them seek
admission in the public and private universities. At present, the number of students in private universities are
increasing.

questions.uddipok: Write a paragraph in 250 words on "Digital Bangladesh".

sub_questions.explanation:
Digital Bangladesh
"Digital Bangladesh" is a visionary initiative launched by the government of Bangladesh to transform the country into a knowledge-based society through the use of information and communication technology (ICT). The concept, introduced by Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina in 2008, aims to harness the power of digital technology to improve various sectors, such as education, healthcare, governance, and business, thereby promoting overall national development. One of the key aspects of Digital Bangladesh is the expansion of internet connectivity across the country, including rural areas, which has enabled millions of people to access information, communicate, and participate in the digital economy.
The government has made significant investments in building infrastructure for digital services, including the development of e-governance systems, digital banking, and online education platforms. These initiatives have not only increased the efficiency of public services but have also provided greater transparency and accountability. In education, online learning platforms and digital classrooms have made learning more accessible, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic, when schools shifted to virtual classes.
Furthermore, the rise of the digital economy has created new opportunities for young entrepreneurs in e-commerce, freelancing, and digital marketing. The government's efforts to develop digital skills among the youth through training programs have led to an increase in the number of IT professionals, contributing to the country’s growing tech industry.
Despite the progress, challenges remain, such as digital literacy gaps, cybersecurity concerns, and the need for further infrastructure development in remote areas. However, the vision of Digital Bangladesh continues to evolve, aiming for an inclusive, technology-driven future for all its citizens.

questions.uddipok:
The following is the beginning of a story. Complete it in your own words:
Rima is a girl of HSC 1st year at a renowned college. In the month of February, she was eagerly waiting to join a 'Book Fair' but her parents interrupted her.....

sub_questions.explanation: Rima, a diligent student in her first year of HSC at a prestigious college, had been eagerly anticipating the upcoming Book Fair in the month of February. She had marked the dates on her calendar and spent countless hours imagining herself browsing through the aisles, exploring new titles, and immersing herself in the world of literature. However, her excitement was abruptly interrupted when her parents voiced their concerns about her upcoming exams. They reminded her of the importance of focusing on her studies and cautioned against distractions like the Book Fair. Rima felt a pang of disappointment as she reluctantly agreed to prioritize her studies over her passion for books. Despite her initial disappointment, Rima understood the importance of her education and resolved to channel her enthusiasm into her studies, knowing that the Book Fair would always be there next year. With determination and dedication, she plunged into her books, determined to excel in her exams and pursue her love for literature once her academic responsibilities were fulfilled.

questions.uddipok: The graph below shows an increase in the number of overseas students at the universities which usually takes place over a period of time. Describe the graph in 150 words.

sub_questions.explanation:
The graph illustrates the increase in the number of overseas students at universities over a 20-year period, from 2000 to 2020.
In 2000, the number of international students was relatively low, just above 200. This figure remained almost unchanged until around 2005, showing a very slow rate of growth. However, after 2005, there was a sharp upward trend. The number of overseas students began to rise rapidly and continued to grow steadily through 2010. By this point, the number had reached around 1000 students.
From 2010 to 2015, the growth began to slow down, although it still maintained an upward trajectory. After 2015, the graph shows a plateau, with student numbers leveling off at around 1100, indicating saturation or stabilization in growth.
In summary, the graph depicts a significant rise in the number of international students between 2005 and 2015, followed by a stable period. The overall trend reflects growing global interest in higher education during this time.

questions.uddipok:
Write down the theme of the following poem (not more than 50 words):–
If you fail to see the person
But only see the disability.
Then who is blind?
If you cannot hear
Your brother's
Cry for justice,
Who is deaf?
If you do not communicate
With your sister
But separate her from you
Who is the mentally handicapped?
If you do not stand up
For the rights of all persons.
Who is crippled?
Your attitude
Towards persons with disabilities,
May be our biggest handicap.

sub_questions.explanation: Theme : The poet here attempts to bring out our true disabilities. He expresses that our narrow-minded attitude is our disability. So, the theme of the poem is that disabilities lie in our mind and attitude, not in our body. The disabled people should not be judged by their disability; rather, they should be judged by their qualities.
